Clean timeseries 0.0.3 documentation

kep.parser package

«  kep.loader package   ::   Contents   ::   kep.session package  »

kep.parser package¶

kep.parser.filters¶

Filter digits from CSV file.

Bad friends:

  • ‘1001)’ (a comment)
  • ‘1001)2)’ (two comments)
  • ‘…’ (omission)
  • ‘-‘ (omission)
kep.parser.filters.clean_year(year: str) → int¶
kep.parser.filters.clean_value(x: str) → float¶
kep.parser.filters.is_omission(x: str) → bool¶

True if x is any of [‘’, ‘…’, ‘-‘]

kep.parser.worker¶

kep.parser.worker.get_parsed_tables(base_mapper, tables, commands, expected_labels=None)¶

Parse tables using base_mapper and commands and check for expected_labels.

Parameters:
  • base_mapper – a UnitMapper instance
  • tables – list of Table instances
  • commands – list of (method, arg) tuples
  • labels (expected) – list of strings
Returns:

list of parsed Table() instances
class kep.parser.worker.Worker(tables, base_mapper: kep.parser.units.UnitMapper)¶

Bases: object

Parse tables using base_mapper and .apply(command).

Limit scope of tables:

  • start_with
  • end_with

Parse tables:

  • name
  • headers
  • units

Handle special situaltions:

  • force_units
  • force_format
  • trail_down_names

All methods above are valid parsing commands in yaml file.

new()¶

Create a copy of this instance.

apply(method, arg=None)¶

Run a command on itself.

start_with(start_strings)¶

Limit parsing segment starting from any of start_strings.

end_with(end_strings)¶

Limit parsing segment ending by any of end_strings.

var(name: str)¶

Set current variable name for parsing.

headers(headers)¶

Set headers strings corresponding to variable name. Works after .var().

units(units)¶

Set list of units for parsing.

parse_units()¶

Identify units using standard units mapper.

force_units(unit: str)¶

All tables in segment will be assigned this unit of measurement.

force_format(fmt: str)¶

Row format for tabels will be assigned to fmt.

trail_down_names()¶

Assign trailing variable names in tables.

We look for a case where a table name is defined once and there are following tables with expected unit names, but no variable name specified.

In this case we assign table name similar to previous table.

parsed_tables¶

kep.parser.reader¶

Convert CSV file to Table() instances. Use get_tables(filepath).

kep.parser.reader.get_tables(source)¶
kep.parser.reader.get_csv(filepath)¶
class kep.parser.reader.Table(header_strings, datarow_strings, row_format=None, name=None, unit=None)¶

Bases: object

Representation of a table from CSV file.

datarows¶
label¶

Variable identifier like ‘CPI_rog’

contains_any(strings)¶

Return largest string found in table headers.

emit_datapoints()¶

Yield Datapoint() instances from table.

kep.parser.row¶

class kep.parser.row.Datapoint(label, freq, year, month, value)¶

Bases: tuple

freq¶

Alias for field number 1

label¶

Alias for field number 0

month¶

Alias for field number 3

value¶

Alias for field number 4

year¶

Alias for field number 2

kep.parser.row.emit_datapoints(row, label, row_format)¶

Yield Datapoint instances from row.

Parameters:
  • row (list) – list of strings like [‘1999’, ‘100’, ‘100’, ‘100’, ‘100’]
  • label (str) – variable identificator like ‘CPI_rog’
  • row_format (str) – format string like ‘YAQQQQ’

kep.parser.units¶

class kep.parser.units.UnitMapper(listing: dict)¶

Bases: object

Initialise mapper with listing dictionary and use .extract() method to get_parsed_tables text.

extract(text: str) → str¶

Extract unit of measurement from text.

Returns:str like ‘rog’ or ‘bln_usd
kep.parser.units.get_mapper(source: str) → kep.parser.units.UnitMapper¶

Read mapper for source (yaml file or string).
